title: Food Resources Available for Families
source_title: Bogan Weekly News | Smore Newsletters for Education

blocks.content:
Social 

Work 

Spotlight

Social Work Spotlight
Please click the photo above for more Talawanda resources.

summary:
Due to uncertainty about SNAP benefits in November, Talawanda is sharing food resource options:
- **Little Free Pantry** - Located outside main entrance at Bogan, restocked daily
- **Backpack Program** - Small bag of food for students every Thursday
- **Family Food Boxes** - Can be picked up or delivered within 24 hours
- **Community Pantries** - Additional resources linked in the flyer

For help accessing these resources, contact Emily White, Bogan Social Worker at 513-273-3403 or whitee@talawanda.org

The breakfast menu includes items like Mini Chocolate Chip French Toast, Breakfast Bowls, Chocolate Donut Holes, Sausage & Cheese Biscuit Sandwiches, and more throughout the month. 100% fruit juice, assorted fruit selection, and milk are included with every breakfast. The cafeteria is closed November 24-25 and 27-28 for Thanksgiving break.

Contact Ms. Currier or Mrs. Bryan with questions.

title: When to Stay Home from School
source_title: Bogan Weekly News | Smore Newsletters for Education

blocks.content:
Nurse's 

Notes

Nurse's Notes

Updated October 24th
Hi Bogan Families!Cold and flu season are officially here and I wanted to share with you the guidelines on when to keep your sick children at home. This chart touches on more than just cold and flu but is a good reminder to all when we need to stay home and when we are able to return back to school. Please be sure if your child is out sick to call and let our attendance line know they will not be at school. Also, if your child has a doctor's note for excused days, have your child drop that off to the front office.Please click the photo below for information from the CDC.

summary: Cold and flu season guidelines for keeping sick children home have been updated. **Stay home if your child has:** a fever of 100¬∞F or higher, frequent/continual coughing or difficulty breathing, diarrhea or vomiting, body rash with fever, active head lice, eye infection with discharge, or sore throat with congestion. **Return to school when:** fever-free for 24 hours without medication, symptoms are improving, and specific condition requirements are met (e.g., 24 hours after starting antibiotic eye drops, tolerating food for 12 hours after vomiting). If your child is absent, call the attendance line and submit any doctor's notes to the front office. For COVID-19, students can return when fever-free for 24 hours without medication and symptoms are minimal and improving.

PUSH
PUSH provides grants to low-income homeowners in the Talawanda School District for critical and emergency home repairs. Call Jeanne or Sabrina at 513-523-8100 for more information. Application is attached. Http://www.push-oxford.org/

summary: **PUSH** (Preserving and Updating Shelters for Homeowners) provides grants to low-income homeowners in the Talawanda School District for critical and emergency home repairs. For more information or to apply, call Jeanne or Sabrina at **513-523-8100** or visit [www.push-oxford.org](http://www.push-oxford.org/).

title: Tech Healthy Household Parent Presentation
source_title: Bogan Weekly News | Smore Newsletters for Education

blocks.content:
Around 

Talawanda

Around Talawanda

summary:
**Project Reboot + Talawanda School District** presents "Keys to Building a Tech Healthy Household" on **Tuesday, November 18th from 6-7:30 PM at Talawanda High School**. This engaging 60-minute presentation plus 30-minute Q&A, hosted by Dino Ambrosi (Founder of Project Reboot), will cover:
- **Tech Addiction**: Why it happens and how to overcome it
- **How to Discuss Screen Time**: Conversations with kids without eye rolling
- **Practical Tips**: Maintaining balanced relationships with technology

All attendees receive actionable take-home resources and dinner table discussion guides. Event supported by Greater Oxford Community Foundation. More info: https://projectreboot.school

title: Halloween Celebration at Bogan Elementary
source_title: Bogan Weekly News | Smore Newsletters for Education

blocks.content:
Halloween
We will celebrate Halloween at Bogan on Friday, October 31st. Costumes will be permitted with the following guidelines:1. No Costume Masks2. No Props3. Minimal Makeup4. Costumes must be worn to school. There will not be a ‚Äúchange time‚Äù. Please make sure that your child will be able to function comfortably throughout the day (bathroom needs, recess, school work, specials) while wearing his/her costume.Weather permitting, we will have a costume parade outside of the building at 9:30am. If your child is a car rider, you are welcome to pull around and park in our lot to wait for the parade to begin. If it is raining, parents will be permitted to line up in the gym and students will parade through.In addition, many of our classrooms are having Halloween parties. Many teachers are doing many different things, so please look for communication from your child's teacher for their specific plan.If you would not like your child to participate in the Halloween festivities, please let your child's teacher know.

summary: **Halloween will be celebrated on Friday, October 31st** with costumes permitted under specific guidelines: no masks, props, or excessive makeup, and costumes must be worn to school all day. A **costume parade will take place at 9:30am** outside (weather permitting) or in the gym if raining, and parents are welcome to attend. Many classrooms will also host Halloween parties‚Äîcheck with your child's teacher for specific plans. Contact your child's teacher if you prefer they not participate.

title: 3rd Grade State Testing Information
source_title: Bogan Weekly News | Smore Newsletters for Education

blocks.content:
Around 

Bogan

Around Bogan

3rd Grade Testing
Our 3rd grade students will take the fall English Language Arts Ohio State Test this month. Students will test on Tuesday, October 21st and Thursday, October 23rd. We will complete makeups during this week as well. All testing will begin at 9:30am.If you are a 3rd grade parent, we would LOVE for you to write a letter or card of encouragement to your child that they will read before starting the test. If possible, please put the letters in an envelope because we would like for them to be a sweet surprise for our students!We have planned a (short) 3rd grade Pep Rally on Monday, October 20th for our students. The purpose of this pep rally is to build confidence and encouragement.Teachers are also taking time to explain to students what trying their best looks like when taking a test. For example, we encourage students to take their time and check their work. We would appreciate if you would also talk to your student about the importance of doing their best on the test. Students who do their best on the test will be invited to a 3rd grade Movie Party on Friday, October 24th!

summary:
**3rd grade students will take the Ohio State Test for English Language Arts** on **Tuesday, October 21st and Thursday, October 23rd**, beginning at **9:30am**. Parents are encouraged to write letters of encouragement for their child to read before testing (please place in an envelope). A pep rally is scheduled for **Monday, October 20th**, and students who do their best will be invited to a **Movie Party on Friday, October 24th**. Parents should talk with students about trying their best, taking their time, and checking their work.

**5 Tips for Testing Success** (from image):
- Get plenty of rest
- Be on time
- Eat a good breakfast
- Relax & take a deep breath
- Follow your teacher's directions

title: ADHD Research Study for 5th Graders
source_title: Bogan Weekly News | Smore Newsletters for Education

blocks.content:
Cincinnati Children's RISE
The Cincinnati Children‚Äôs RISE: Resilience In Student Education project is offering an important research opportunity focused on understanding and promoting resilience among 5th grade students with ADHD or who experience difficulties with paying attention or hyperactive/impulsive behaviors. Caregivers and students can receive up to $320 for completing questionnaires about academics, organization skills, and social-emotional well-being. Complete our interest form: https://redcap.link/RISEstudy. Contact RISE at RISEstudy@cchmc.org, call 513-803-6321, or visit: studentresilience.orgLINK to Flyer

summary:
**Cincinnati Children's RISE** (Resilience In Student Education) is conducting a research study for 5th grade students with ADHD or attention/hyperactivity challenges. Caregivers and students can **earn up to $320** for completing questionnaires about academics, organization skills, and social-emotional well-being. 

**To participate:**
- Complete the interest form: https://redcap.link/RISEstudy
- Email: RISEstudy@cchmc.org
- Call: 513-803-6321
- Visit: studentresilience.org
